revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 2 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:Hayholt|Hayholt]])
revision.text:
{{italic title|all=yes|string=Star Trek: Deep Space Nine}} The entire series of ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' was released on [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] and [[DVD region code#2|Region 2]] [[DVD]] in 2003. In Region 4, it was released on DVD between May 2003 and May 2004.<ref>http://www.dvdwarehouse.com.au/star-trek-deep-space-nine-season-01-dvd-box-set.html{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>http://www.dvdwarehouse.com.au/star-trek-deep-space-nine-season-07-dvd-box-set-9324915054608.html{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Slimpack versions (like those released in 2006 for ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'') were released in Region 2 areas on April 30, 2007.<ref>[http://www.dvdtimes.co.uk/content.php?contentid=64602 DVD Times - Star Trek: Deep Space Nine ‚ÄúSlims‚Äù in April<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> An entire series boxed set was released in Region 4 on August 6, 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dvdorchard.com.au/165158/star-trek-deep-space-nine-ds9-the-complete-collection-tv-on-dvd |title=Star Trek Deep Space Nine Ds9 The Complete Collection on DVD |last= |first= |author= |date= |year= |website=dvdorchard |publisher=dvdorchard Pty Limited |location= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060153/http://www.dvdorchard.com.au/165158/star-trek-deep-space-nine-ds9-the-complete-collection-tv-on-dvd|archivedate=2016-03-04|deadurl=yes|accessdate={{date|2015-2-1}} |ref= }}</ref>
==Box sets== These are box sets, featuring entire seasons, that have been released on [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] ([[North America]]) and [[DVD region code#2|Region 2]] ([[Europe]]).
===The Complete First Season=== This is the first ''Deep Space Nine'' box set, released on February 25, 2003 on Region 1, March 24, 2003 on Region 2, and May 9, 2003 on Region 4.
====Episodes==== '''Disc 1:''' * "[[Emissary (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Emissary]]" * "[[Past Prologue]]" * "[[A Man Alone (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|A Man Alone]]"
'''Disc 2:''' * "[[Babel (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Babel]]" * "[[Captive Pursuit]]" * "[[Q-Less]]" * "[[Dax (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Dax]]"
'''Disc 3:''' * "[[The Passenger (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Passenger]]" * "[[Move Along Home]]" * "[[The Nagus]]" * "[[Vortex (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Vortex]]"
'''Disc 4:''' * "[[Battle Lines (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Battle Lines]]" * "[[The Storyteller (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Storyteller]]" * "[[Progress (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Progress]]" * "[[If Wishes Were Horses]]"
'''Disc 5:''' * "[[The Forsaken (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Forsaken]]" * "[[Dramatis Personae (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Dramatis Personae]]" * "[[Duet (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Duet]]" * "[[In the Hands of the Prophets]]"
'''Disc 6:''' *Special Features
====Special Features==== * ''Deep Space Nine: A Bold New Beginning'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Kira Nerys]]'' * ''[[Michael Westmore]]'s Aliens: Season One'' * ''Secrets of Quark's Bar'' * ''Alien Artifacts: Season One'' * ''Deep Space Nine Sketchbook'' * ''Original Deep Space Nine preview'' * ''Photo gallery''
===The Complete Second Season=== This is the second ''Deep Space Nine'' box set, released on April 1, 2003 on Region 1, April 28, 2003 on Region 2, and July 3, 2003 on Region 4.
====Episodes==== '''Disc 1:''' * "[[The Homecoming (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Homecoming]]" * "[[The Circle (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Circle]]" * "[[The Siege (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Siege]]" * "[[Invasive Procedures (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Invasive Procedures]]"
'''Disc 2:''' * "[[Cardassians (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Cardassians]]" * "[[Melora (Star Trek Deep Space Nine)|Melora]]" * "[[Rules of Acquisition (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Rules of Acquisition]]" * "[[Necessary Evil (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Necessary Evil]]"
'''Disc 3:''' * "[[Second Sight (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Second Sight]]" * "[[Sanctuary (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Sanctuary]]" * "[[Rivals (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Rivals]]" * "[[The Alternate (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Alternate]]"
'''Disc 4:''' * "[[Armageddon Game]]" * "[[Whispers (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Whispers]]" * "[[Paradise (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Paradise]]" * "[[Shadowplay (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Shadowplay]]"
'''Disc 5:''' * "[[Playing God (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Playing God]]" * "[[Profit and Loss (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Profit and Loss]]" * "[[Blood Oath (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Blood Oath]]" * "[[The Maquis]]"
'''Disc 6:''' * "[[The Maquis]] (Part II)" * "[[The Wire (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Wire]]" * "[[Crossover (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Crossover]]" * "[[The Collaborator (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Collaborator]]"
'''Disc 7:''' * "[[Tribunal (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Tribunal]]" * "[[The Jem'Hadar]]" *Special features
====Special Features==== * ''New Frontiers: The Story Of Deep Space Nine'' * ''Michael Westmore's Aliens: Season Two'' * ''Deep Space Nine Sketchbook: Season Two'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Jadzia Dax]]'' * ''New Station, New Ships'' * ''Quark's Story'' * ''Photo Gallery''
===The Complete Third Season=== This is the third ''Deep Space Nine'' box set, released on June 3, 2003 on Region 1, June 23, 2003 on Region 2, and September 4, 2003 on Region 4.
====Episodes==== '''Disc 1:''' * "[[The Search (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Search]]" * "[[The Search (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Search]], Part II" * "[[The House of Quark]]" * "[[Equilibrium (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Equilibrium]]"
'''Disc 2:''' * "[[Second Skin (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Second Skin]]" * "[[The Abandoned (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Abandoned]]" * "[[Civil Defense (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Civil Defense]]" * "[[Meridian (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Meridian]]"
'''Disc 3:''' * "[[Defiant (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Defiant]]" * "[[Fascination (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Fascination]]" * "[[Past Tense (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Past Tense]], Part I" * "[[Past Tense (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Past Tense]], Part II"
'''Disc 4:''' * "[[Life Support (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Life Support]]" * "[[Heart of Stone (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Heart of Stone]]" * "[[Destiny (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Destiny]]" * "[[Prophet Motive]]"
'''Disc 5:''' * "[[Visionary (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Visionary]]" * "[[Distant Voices (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Distant Voices]]" * "[[Through the Looking Glass (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Through the Looking Glass]]" * "[[Improbable Cause]]"
'''Disc 6:''' * "[[The Die is Cast (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Die is Cast]]" * "[[Explorers (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Explorers]]" * "[[Family Business (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Family Business]]" * "[[Shakaar]]"
'''Disc 7:''' * "[[Facets (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Facets]]" * "[[The Adversary (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Adversary]]" *Special features
====Special Features==== * ''The Birth of the [[Dominion (Star Trek)|Dominion]] and Beyond'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Odo (Star Trek)|Odo]]'' * ''U.S.S. Defiant'' * ''Time Travel Files: "Past Tense"'' * ''Sailing Through the Stars: A Special Look at "Explorers"'' * ''Michael Westmore's Aliens, Season Three''
===The Complete Fourth Season=== This is the fourth ''Deep Space Nine'' box set, released on August 5, 2003 on Region 1, August 25, 2003 on Region 2, and November 12, 2003 on Region 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaeldvd.com.au/Reviews/Reviews.asp?ID=3756|title=Star Trek: Deep Space Nine-Complete Season 4 (1995)|website=www.michaeldvd.com.au}}</ref>
====Episodes==== '''Disc 1:''' * "[[The Way of the Warrior (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Way of the Warrior]]" * "[[The Visitor (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Visitor]]" * "[[Hippocratic Oath (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Hippocratic Oath]]"
'''Disc 2:''' * "[[Indiscretion (Star Trek Deep Space Nine)|Indiscretion]]" * "[[Rejoined]]" * "[[Starship Down (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Starship Down]]" * "[[Little Green Men (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Little Green Men]]"
'''Disc 3:''' * "[[The Sword of Kahless]]" * "[[Our Man Bashir]]" * "[[Homefront (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Homefront]]" * "[[Paradise Lost (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Paradise Lost]]"
'''Disc 4:''' * "[[Crossfire (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Crossfire]]" * "[[Return to Grace]]" * "[[Sons of Mogh]]" * "[[Bar Association (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Bar Association]]"
'''Disc 5:''' * "[[Accession (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Accession]]" * "[[Rules of Engagement (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Rules of Engagement]]" * "[[Hard Time (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Hard Time]]" * "[[Shattered Mirror (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Shattered Mirror]]"
'''Disc 6:''' * "[[The Muse (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Muse]]" * "[[For the Cause (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|For the Cause]]" * "[[To the Death (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|To the Death]]" * "[[The Quickening (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Quickening]]"
'''Disc 7:''' * "[[Body Parts (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Body Parts]]" * "[[Broken Link (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Broken Link]]" *Special features
====Special Features==== * ''Charting New Territory: Deep Space Nine Season Four'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Worf]]'' * ''Michael Westmore's Aliens, Season Four'' * ''Deep Space Nine Sketchbook * ''[[Robert Blackman]]'s Designs of the Future'' * ''Jim Martin's Sketchbook'' * ''Deep Space Nine Chronicles'' * ''Photo Gallery''
===The Complete Fifth Season=== This is the fifth ''Deep Space Nine'' box set, released on October 7, 2003 on Region 1, October 27, 2003 on Region 2, and January 15, 2004 on Region 4.
====Episodes==== '''Disc 1:''' * "[[Apocalypse Rising]]" * "[[The Ship (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Ship]]" * "[[Looking for par'Mach in All the Wrong Places]]" * "[[...Nor the Battle to the Strong]]"
'''Disc 2:''' * "[[The Assignment (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Assignment]]" * "[[Trials and Tribble-ations]]" * "[[Let He Who Is Without Sin...]]" * "[[Things Past (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Things Past]]"
'''Disc 3:''' * "[[The Ascent (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Ascent]]" * "[[Rapture (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Rapture]]" * "[[The Darkness and the Light (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Darkness and the Light]]" * "[[The Begotten]]"
'''Disc 4:''' * "[[For the Uniform]]" * "[[In Purgatory's Shadow]]" * "[[By Inferno's Light]]" * "[[Doctor Bashir, I Presume?]]"
'''Disc 5:''' * "[[A Simple Investigation]]" * "[[Business as Usual (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Business as Usual]]" * "[[Ties of Blood and Water]]" * "[[Ferengi Love Songs]]"
'''Disc 6:''' * "[[Soldiers of the Empire]]" * "[[Children of Time (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Children of Time]]" * "[[Blaze of Glory (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Blaze of Glory]]" * "[[Empok Nor]]"
'''Disc 7:''' * "[[In the Cards]]" * "[[Call to Arms (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Call to Arms]]" *Special features
====Special Features==== * ''Trials and Tribble-ations: Uniting Two Legends'' * ''Trials and Tribble-ations: A Historic Endeavor'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Miles O'Brien (Star Trek)|Miles O'Brien]]'' * ''Inside DS9 with [[Michael Okuda]]'' * ''Michael Westmore's Aliens: Season 5'' * ''Deep Space Nine Sketchbook'' * ''The [[Ferengi]] Culture'' * ''Photo Gallery''
===The Complete Sixth Season=== This is the sixth ''Deep Space Nine'' box set, released on November 4, 2003 on Region 1, December 8, 2003 on Region 2, and March 4, 2004 on Region 4.
====Episodes==== '''Disc 1:''' * "[[A Time to Stand]]" * "[[Rocks and Shoals (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Rocks and Shoals]]" * "[[Sons and Daughters (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Sons and Daughters]]" * "[[Behind the Lines (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Behind the Lines]]"
'''Disc 2:''' * "[[Favor the Bold]]" * "[[Sacrifice of Angels]]" * "[[You Are Cordially Invited...]]" * "[[Resurrection (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Resurrection]]"
'''Disc 3:''' * "[[Statistical Probabilities]]" * "[[The Magnificent Ferengi]]" * "[[Waltz (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Waltz]]" * "[[Who Mourns for Morn?]]"
'''Disc 4:''' * "[[Far Beyond the Stars]]" * "[[One Little Ship]]" * "[[Honor Among Thieves (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Honor Among Thieves]]" * "[[Change of Heart (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Change of Heart]]"
'''Disc 5:''' * "[[Wrongs Darker than Death or Night]]" * "[[Inquisition (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Inquisition]]" * "[[In the Pale Moonlight]]" * "[[His Way]]"
'''Disc 6:''' * "[[The Reckoning (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Reckoning]]" * "[[Valiant (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Valiant]]" * "[[Profit and Lace]]" * "[[Time's Orphan]]"
'''Disc 7:''' * "[[The Sound of Her Voice]]" * "[[Tears of the Prophets]]" *Special features
====Special Features==== * ''Mission Inquiry: "Far Beyond the Stars"'' * ''24th century wedding'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Julian Bashir]]'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Quark (Star Trek)|Quark]]'' * ''Deep Space Nine Sketchbook'' * ''[[Gary Hutzel]] on "One Little Ship"'' * ''Ferengi [[Rules of Acquisition]]: The Beginning'' * ''Ferengi Rules of Acquisition: The Sequel'' * ''Photo Gallery''
===The Complete Seventh Season=== This is the seventh and final ''Deep Space Nine'' box set, released on December 2, 2003 on Region 1, December 22, 2003 on Region 2, and May 6, 2004 on Region 4.
====Episodes==== '''Disc 1:''' * "[[Image in the Sand]]" * "[[Shadows and Symbols]]" * "[[Afterimage (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Afterimage]]" * "[[Take Me Out to the Holosuite]]"
'''Disc 2:''' * "[[Chrysalis (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Chrysalis]]" * "[[Treachery, Faith, and the Great River]]" * "[[Once More Unto the Breach (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Once More Unto the Breach]]" * "[[The Siege of AR-558]]"
'''Disc 3:''' * "[[Covenant (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Covenant]]" * "[[It's Only a Paper Moon (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|It's Only a Paper Moon]]" * "[[Prodigal Daughter (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Prodigal Daughter]]" * "[[The Emperor's New Cloak]]"
'''Disc 4:''' * "[[Field of Fire (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Field of Fire]]" * "[[Chimera (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Chimera]]" * "[[Badda-Bing Badda-Bang]]" * "[[Inter Arma Enim Silent Leges (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Inter Arma Enim Silent Leges]]"
'''Disc 5:''' * "[[Penumbra (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Penumbra]]" * "[[‚ÄôTil Death Do Us Part (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|'Til Death Do Us Part]]" * "[[Strange Bedfellows (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Strange Bedfellows]]" * "[[The Changing Face of Evil]]"
'''Disc 6:''' * "[[When It Rains‚Ä¶]]" * "[[Tacking Into the Wind]]" * "[[Extreme Measures (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Extreme Measures]]" * "[[The Dogs of War (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Dogs of War]]"
'''Disc 7:''' * "[[What You Leave Behind]]" *Special features
====Special Features==== * ''Ending An Era'' * ''The Last Goodbyes'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Benjamin Sisko]]'' * ''Crew Dossier: [[Jake Sisko]]'' * ''Special Crew Dossier: [[Ezri Dax]]'' * ''[[List of recurring characters in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine#Morn|Morn]] Speaks'' * ''Deep Space Nine Sketchbook'' * ''Photo Gallery''
==Easter eggs== All of the box sets feature easy to find [[Easter egg (media)|easter eggs]]. They include interviews with cast members, guest stars and production staff. They are known as "[[Section 31]] files".
==Fan Collectives== Several ''Deep Space Nine'' episodes feature in the 2006 [[Star Trek]] Fan Collective DVDs.
===Time Travel DVD=== * "[[Little Green Men (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Little Green Men]]" (with text commentary) * "[[Trials and Tribble-ations]]"
===Q DVD=== * "[[Q-Less]]" (with text commentary)
===Klingon DVD=== * "[[The Way of the Warrior (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|The Way of the Warrior]]" * "[[The Sword of Kahless]]" * "[[Trials and Tribble-ations]]"
===Captain's Log DVD=== * "[[Far Beyond the Stars]]" * "[[What You Leave Behind]]" * "[[In the Pale Moonlight]]"
===Alternate Realities DVD=== * "[[Crossover (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Crossover]]" * "[[Through the Looking Glass (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Through the Looking Glass]]" * "[[Shattered Mirror (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|Shattered Mirror]]" :Participants were also allowed to vote for any of the seven hundred plus ''[[Star Trek]]'' episodes for inclusion on the DVD. The focus was on episodes such as "[[Far Beyond the Stars]]".<ref>[http://www.startrek.com/surveys/dvd/intro.jsp Star Trek DVD Survey - Introduction<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050416002238/http://www.startrek.com/surveys/dvd/intro.jsp |date=April 16, 2005 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Memory Alpha|DVD#Star Trek: Deep Space Nine DVDs|Star Trek: Deep Space Nine DVDs}}

page.title: List of video game soundtracks released on vinyl

revision.comment: Removing link(s) to "GameZone": Article deleted per [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/GameZone]]. | [[WP:TW|TW]]
revision.text:
{{Inc-musong}}
The practice of '''releasing [[video game soundtrack]]s on''' [[gramophone record|'''vinyl''' record]]s began in the 1980s, fell out of favor in the 1990s and 2000s as vinyl records were replaced by other storage media, and experienced a resurgence of interest in the 2010s due in part to a [[vinyl revival]].<ref name=napolitano/>
==History== Vinyl recordings of video game music find their origins in the 1970s with early experiments by [[Kraftwerk]]<ref name=dreamboum/> and [[album]]s such as [[Yellow Magic Orchestra]]'s [[Yellow Magic Orchestra (album)|self-titled 1978 release]] sampling electronic music from the games ''[[Circus (video game)|Circus]]'', ''[[Space Invaders]]'', and ''[[Gun Fight]]''.<ref name=napolitano/> In 1984, [[Haruomi Hosono]] released the first generally recognized video game soundtrack album, ''Video Game Music'',<ref name=dreamboum/><ref name=savorelli/> and the practice experienced its "golden age" in the mid-to-late 1980s with hundreds of releases including [[Buckner & Garcia]]'s ''[[Pac-Man Fever (album)|Pac-Man Fever]]'', [[Namco]]'s ''Video Game Graffiti'', and [[Koichi Sugiyama]]'s orchestral covers of the [[Dragon Quest|''Dragon Quest'' series]].<ref name=napolitano/> The 1990s saw many fewer commercial releases and a shift to [[Promo (media)|promo releases]] with increasing use of video game [[Sampling (music)|samples]] in rap<ref name=spin/> and hip hop.<ref name=webster/>
The trend away from vinyl discs continued in the 2000s as fan-made remixes also began to be produced, however by the 2010s the trend reversed and the practice of producing video game soundtracks on vinyl experienced a revival.<ref name=napolitano/><ref name=jackson/> The vinyl revival of the 2010s has itself been attributed to inspiration in younger music buyers from video games,<ref name=mcgeehan/> and it has led to the establishment of video game soundtrack oriented vinyl record labels like [[Black Screen Records]],<ref name=diver/> [[Data Discs]],<ref name=parish/> [[Brave Wave]], and [[iam8bit]],<ref name=beaumontthomas/> and shifts toward similar releases for labels like [[Ghost Ramp]],<ref name=kelly/><ref name=tomer/> [[Ship To Shore Phonograph Co.]],<ref name=eckhardt/> and [[Mondo Tees]].<ref name=greenwald/> In a 2015 article, music journalist [[Mike Diver]] suggested that "this scene within a scene is experiencing boom times", however he noted that some in the music industry, including [[Invada Records|Invada]] manager Redg Weeks, were concerned by the risk of [[Market saturation|over-saturation of the market]].<ref name=diver/> These concerns were later repeated by Jamie Crook of Data Discs,<ref name=parish/> and although he has joined Mondo's Mo Shafeek in arguing that the vinyl medium itself and the related revival is in no way a fad or bubble,<ref name=gach/> in 2017 ''Kotaku'' reported concerns from dedicated video game soundtrack labels that pressing plants were scheduling their manufacturing runs last in order to favor traditional labels.<ref name=jackson/>
The 2000s-2010s revival of interest in this medium has been characterized by releases [[Limited edition (music)|in limited numbers]] and promotional albums only available at special events or as pre-order bonuses.<ref name=napolitano/> In addition, the practice has been adopted by the [[Cult video game|cult]]<ref name=greenwald/> and [[Indie game]] scenes, with its proponents citing audio quality,<ref name=napolitano/> interactivity,<ref name=napolitano/><ref name=johnson/> artwork,<ref name=napolitano/><ref name=eldred/> nostalgia,<ref name=diver/><ref name=eldred/> unique content,<ref name=eldred/><ref name=troper/> and the fact that vinyl albums represent tangible aspects of intangible ([[Digital distribution|digitally distributed]]) products<ref name=diver/><ref name=johnson/><ref name=eldred/> as key elements to what makes vinyl soundtrack albums attractive. Additional considerations for collectors include archival and preservation aspects for older games,<ref name=roberts/> examination and recontextualization of the music as a means to expand or further explore the game,<ref name=eckhardt/><ref name=troper/> and curiosity among audiophiles unfamiliar with video gaming music as a genre.<ref name=roberts/> Due to the limited nature of modern releases, many albums are considered highly collectible, with some regularly selling in excess of $100 USD. For Western collectors, additional difficulty is imposed by the cost of importing albums from Japan where the majority were produced during the "golden age" of the 1980s.<ref name=diver/><ref name=eldred/>
== Soundtrack albums ==
=== 1990s‚Äì2010 ===
{| class="wikitable sortable" width="100%" |- ! Rel. !! OST Title !! Game Title !! [[Record Label|Label]] !! Notes !! Ref(s) |- | 1996 || [[Wipeout 2097: The Soundtrack]] || [[Wipeout 2097]] || [[Virgin Records]] || 2xLP on black vinyl. || <ref>Valentine, Dave and Chris Greening. "[http://www.vgmonline.net/timwrightinterview/ Tim Wright (aka CoLD SToRAGE) Interview: From Lemmings to Wipeout]". ''VGMOnline''. 7 May 2010.</ref> |- | 1997 || [[Ghost in the Shell (video game)#Soundtrack|Ghost In The Shell - PlayStation Soundtrack]] || [[Ghost in the Shell (video game)|Ghost in the Shell]] || [[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony Music]] || 2xLP on black vinyl. || <ref name=napolitano/> |- | 2001 || Grand Theft Auto III Single|| [[Grand Theft Auto III]] || Game Recordings || Album sampler. Side One: 'Rising to the Top' Radio Version, Street Version and Instrumental. == Vinyl data == The use of grooved vinyl discs as a [[Sequencer (musical instrument)|sequenced/encoded]] rather than [[Analog recording|recorded]] data storage medium enabled the code of [[full motion video|full motion videos (FMVs)]] and even simple video games to be stored in an [[Analog recording|analog format]] along with the soundtrack and sound effects. These vinyl data discs took two forms: the FMV-only [[Capacitance Electronic Disc|Capacitance Electronic Disc (CED)]], and the program sheet. Uncommon even in the early 1980s when the practice was at its height, program sheet game data required that users [[Sound recording and reproduction|record]] from the disc (typically a [[flexi disc]] like the ''Interface Age'' "[[Floppy ROM]]") onto an [[audio cassette tape]] which could then be used via the cassette port with microcomputers such as the [[BBC Micro]], [[Commodore 64]], [[Commodore PET]], [[Commodore VIC-20]], [[Dragon 32/64]], [[ZX81]], or [[ZX Spectrum]].<ref name=arendt/> The use of CEDs to store video game FMV data was even less common, and required the game console (typically an [[arcade machine]]) to select a section of the grooved track to read with its [[record needle|stylus]] at just the right time for the video to be displayed. The numerous limitations of these techniques ([[background noise]], [[Abrasion (mechanical)|scratches]], and [[Broken record|other audio-fidelity problems]])<ref name=arendt/><ref name="bennett82-06"/><ref name=smith/> contributed to their failure to receive widespread acceptance and video game data stored in this manner remains some of the most difficult to archive and preserve.<ref name=off/>

This article provides a '''list of notable awards for [[webcomic]]s''' and some of the winners from each year. Many webcomics artists have received honors for their work. In 2006, [[Gene Luen Yang]]'s graphic novel ''[[American Born Chinese]]'', originally published as a webcomic on [[Modern Tales]], was the first graphic novel to be nominated for a [[National Book Award]].Bosman, Julie. (October 12, 2006). "National Book Award Finalists Chosen". ''[[The New York Times]]'', Pg. E2 [[Don Hertzfeldt]]'s animated film based on his webcomics, ''[[Everything Will Be OK]]'', won the 2007 [[Sundance Film Festival]] Jury Award in Short Filmmaking, a prize rarely bestowed on an animated film.{{cite news|title=Bay Area films keep it real at Sundance festival|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4176/is_20070116/ai_n17130219/pg_2/|accessdate=2007-01-16|author=De Benedetti, Chris |publisher=Oakland Tribune}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} Webcomic artists have also won comic awards from organizations that generally honor print comics, such as the [[Ignatz Awards]] and [[Eisner Awards]], and there are awards, such as the [[Web Cartoonists' Choice Awards]], which are given only to webcomics. ==Awards given only to webcomics== ===Web Cartoonists' Choice Awards=== [[File:SMBC comic 25 March 2008, with caption.png|thumb|right|[[Saturday Morning Breakfast Cereal]] won "Outstanding Single Panel Comic" at the 2006 and 2007 Web Cartoonist's Choice Awards.{{cite news|url=http://ryanestrada.com/wcca/ceremony/singlepanel.htm|title=Outstanding Single Panel Comic by Josh Rosen of Edwitch|work=2006 Ceremony|author=[[Web Cartoonists' Choice Awards]]; Presenter: Josh Rosen|year=2006|accessdate=February 21, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ccawards.com/2007.htm |title=The 2007 Cartoonist's Choice Awards |work=2007 Ceremony |author=[[Web Cartoonists' Choice Awards]] |year=2007 |accessdate=February 21, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5p9JLT7dk?url=http://www.ccawards.com/2007.htm |archivedate=April 21, 2010 |df= }}]] From 2001 until 2008, the [[Web Cartoonists' Choice Awards]] were given out, with voting rights granted only to online [[cartoonist]]s. Because of the large number of categories, such as "Best Art", "Best Writing", "Best Gag Comic" and "Best Newcomer", only the winners of the main category "Best Comic" are listed here. The following articles provide complete listings of all nominees and winners in each year: {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! colspan="4" | Best Comic (2001 ‚Äì 2002), Outstanding Comic (2003 ‚Äì 2008) |- ! Year ! Title ! Creator(s) ! Website |- | '''2001''' [https://www.webcitation.org/5p9IkMRFf?url=http://www.ccawards.com/2001.htm] | ''[[Boxjam's Doodle]]'' | Adam Burke | [http://www.boxjamsdoodle.com/ www.boxjamsdoodle.com] |- | '''2002''' [https://web.archive.org/web/20091208130436/http://www.ccawards.com/2002.htm] | ''[[Megatokyo]]'' | [[Fred Gallagher (cartoonist)|Fred Gallagher]] and [[Rodney Caston]] | [http://www.megatokyo.com/ www.megatokyo.com] |- | '''2003''' [https://web.archive.org/web/20120204065759/http://www.ccawards.com/2003.htm] | ''[[Nowhere Girl]]'' | Justine Shaw | [http://www.nowheregirl.com/ www.nowheregirl.com] |- | '''2004''' [https://www.webcitation.org/5p9J1fGwz?url=http://www.ccawards.com/2004.htm] | ''[[Count Your Sheep]]'' | Adrian Ramos | [http://www.countyoursheep.com/ www.countyoursheep.com] |- | '''2005''' [https://www.webcitation.org/5p9JJLQxp?url=http://www.ccawards.com/2005.htm] | ''[[Scary Go Round]]'' | [[John Allison (comics)|John Allison]] | [http://www.scarygoround.com/ www.scarygoround.com] |- | '''2006''' | ''[[The Perry Bible Fellowship]]'' | Nicholas Gurewitch | [http://www.pbfcomics.com/ www.pbfcomics.com] |- | '''2007''' | ''The Perry Bible Fellowship'' | Nicholas Gurewitch | [http://www.pbfcomics.com/ www.pbfcomics.com] |- | '''2008''' [https://web.archive.org/web/20090310200607/http://www.ccawards.com/2008finalists.html] | ''[[Girl Genius]]'' | [[Phil Foglio]] and [[Kaja Foglio]] | [http://www.girlgenius.net/ www.girlgenius.net] |} ===The Webcomic List Awards=== In 2009 and 2010, users of [[internet forum]] The Webcomic List held an amateur award ceremony, where winners of its various categories were selected through a panel of judges. The ceremony itself was presented in the form of a webcomic, allowing it to spoof televised award shows as well as exhibit sample portions of the awardees.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbr.com/the-webcomic-list-awards-are-presented-in-a-webcomic/|work=[[Comic Book Resources]]|title=The Webcomic List Awards are presented‚Ä¶ in a webcomic|last=Alverson|first=Brigid|date=2011-02-03}}{{cite web|url=http://www.comicsbeat.com/2010-webcomic-list-award-winners/|work=Comics Beat|title=2010 Webcomic List Award Winners|last=MacDonald|first=Heidi|author-link=Heidi MacDonald|date=2011-02-03}} ==Awards from organizations that generally honor print comics== ===Eagle Awards=== {{Main|Eagle Award (comics)}} The Eagle Award is a series of awards for comic book titles and creators. They are awarded by UK fan voting for work produced during the previous year. The awards featured a "favourite web-based comic" category from 2001 until its discontinuation in 2012. {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! colspan="4" | Favourite Web-based Comic |- ! Year ! Title ! Creator(s) ! Website |- | 2001 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140222133803/http://www.eagleawards.co.uk/category/previous-winners/2001/] | ''[[Sluggy Freelance]]'' | [[Pete Abrams]] | [http://www.sluggy.com/ www.sluggy.com] |- | 2005 [https://web.archive.org/web/20131023083637/http://www.eagleawards.co.uk/category/previous-winners/2005/] | ''[[PvP]]'' | [[Scott Kurtz]] | [http://www.pvponline.com/ www.pvponline.com] |- | 2006 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140222134431/http://www.eagleawards.co.uk/category/previous-winners/2006/] | ''[[Supernatural Law]]'' | [[Batton Lash]] | [https://web.archive.org/web/20150326001307/http://www.webcomicsnation.com/supernaturallaw/index.php www.webcomicsnation.com] |- | 2007 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140222134256/http://www.eagleawards.co.uk/category/previous-winners/2007/] | ''[[Penny Arcade (webcomic)|Penny Arcade]]'' | [[Jerry Holkins]] (writer) and [[Mike Krahulik]] (artist) | [http://www.penny-arcade.com/ www.penny-arcade.com] |- | 2008 [https://web.archive.org/web/20131023120223/http://www.eagleawards.co.uk/category/previous-winners/2008/] | ''[[The Order of the Stick]]'' | [[Rich Burlew]] | [http://www.giantitp.com/comics/ootslatest.html www.giantitp.com] |- | 2010 [https://web.archive.org/web/20120314223212/http://www.eagleawards.co.uk/category/previous-winners/2010/] | ''[[FreakAngels]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.comicsbeat.com/2010/10/30/2010-eagle-award-winners/ |title=2010 Eagle Award winners |date=2010-10-30 |publisher=Comics Beat |accessdate=22 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726121848/http://www.comicsbeat.com/2010/10/30/2010-eagle-award-winners/ |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df= }} | [[Warren Ellis]] and Paul Duffield | [http://www.freakangels.com/ www.freakangels.com] |- | 2011 [https://web.archive.org/web/20120314223719/http://www.eagleawards.co.uk/category/previous-winners/2011/] | ''[[Axe Cop]]'' | [[Ethan Nicolle]] and Malachai Nicolle | [http://www.axecop.com/ www.axecop.com] |- | 2012 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140226104723/http://www.eagleawards.co.uk/category/previous-winners/2012/] | ''FreakAngels'' | Warren Ellis and Paul Duffield | [http://www.freakangels.com/ www.freakangels.com] |} ===Eisner Award=== {{Main|List_of_Eisner_Award_winners#Best_Digital_Comic/Webcomic}} The Will Eisner Comic Industry Award, commonly shortened to the Eisner Award, is a prize given for creative achievement in American comic books. In 2003, Justine Shaw's ''[[Nowhere Girl]]'' received a nomination for an Eisner award in the "best new series" category, while Shaw was nominated for "talent deserving of wider recognition", making her the first webcomic artist to be nominated for an Eisner.Price, Matthew (April 18, 2003). "DC leads in nominations; Norman artist in race for award". ''[[The Daily Oklahoman]]'', p. 21D. ''[[Paste Magazine]]'' noted in 2016 that the Eisner's conflation of "[[digital comic]]" and "webcomic" may cause independent works to be overshadowed by online services such as [[Marvel Unlimited]] and [[DC Comics]]' "Digital First".{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/05/why-the-eisners-need-to-show-webcomics-some-love.html|work=[[Paste Magazine]]|title=Why The Eisners Need to Show Webcomics Some Love|last=Rosberg|first=Caitlin|date=2016-05-25}} In 2017, it was split into "Best Digital Comic" and "Best Webcomic". {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! colspan="4" | Best Digital Comic (2005 ‚Äì 2008), Best Webcomic (2009 ‚Äì ‚Ä¶) |- ! Year ! Title ! Creator(s) ! Website |- | 2005 [http://www.hahnlibrary.net/comics/awards/eisner05.php] | ''[[Mom's Cancer]]'' | Brian Fies | [http://www.momscancer.com/ momscancer.com] (webcomic has since gone offline) |- | 2006 [http://www.hahnlibrary.net/comics/awards/eisner06.php] | ''[[PvP]]'' | [[Scott Kurtz]] | [http://www.pvponline.com/ pvponline.com] |- | 2007 [http://www.hahnlibrary.net/comics/awards/eisner07.php] | ''[[Sam & Max#Comic books|Sam & Max: The Big Sleep]]'' | [[Steve Purcell]] | [http://www.telltalegames.com/community/comics/samandmax/issue-1/ telltalegames.com] |- | 2008 | ''[[Sugarshock!]]'' | [[Joss Whedon]] (writer) and [[F√°bio Moon]] (artist) | website is offline |- | 2009 | ''[[Finder (comics)|Finder]]'' | [[Carla Speed McNeil]] | [http://www.shadowlinecomics.com/webcomics/#/finder/ shadowlinecomics.com] |- | 2010 | ''[[Sin Titulo]]'' | [[Cameron Stewart]] | [http://www.sintitulocomic.com sintitulocomic.com] |- | 2011 | ''[[The Abominable Charles Christopher]]'' | [[Karl Kerschl]] | [http://abominable.cc abominable.cc] |- | 2012 | ''[[Battlepug]]'' | [[Mike Norton]] | [http://www.battlepug.com battlepug.com] |- | 2013 | ''Bandette'' | [[Paul Tobin (author)|Paul Tobin]] and Colleen Coover | [[Comixology]] |- | 2014 | ''[[The Oatmeal]]'' | Matthew Inman | [http://theoatmeal.com/ theoatmeal.com] |- | 2015 | ''[[The Private Eye]]'' | [[Brian K. Vaughan]] and [[Marcos Mart√≠n]] | [http://panelsyndicate.com/ panelsyndicate.com] |- | 2016 | ''Bandette'' | [[Paul Tobin (author)|Paul Tobin]] and Colleen Coover | [https://www.comixology.com/Bandette/comics-series/8519 available] on [[Comixology]] |- | 2017 | ''Bird Boy'' | Anne Szabla | [http://bird-boy.com bird-boy.com] |- | 2018 | ''The Tea Dragon Society'' | Katie O'Neill | [http://teadragonsociety.com teadragonsociety.com] |} ===Harvey Awards=== {{Main|List of Harvey Award winners#Best Online Comics Work}} The Harvey Awards, named for writer-artist [[Harvey Kurtzman]] (1924-1993) and coordinated by the publisher [[Fantagraphics]], are given for achievement in comic books. The Harveys were created as part of a successor to the [[Kirby Awards]] which were discontinued after 1987. Following the revamp in 2018 after the awards moved to [[New York Comic Con]], the "Best Online Comics Work" has been renamed "Digital Book of the Year".{{cite web |last1=McDonald |first1=Heidi |title=Details of the 2018 Harvey Awards announced and it‚Äôs a big change |url=http://www.comicsbeat.com/details-of-the-2018-harvey-awards-announced-and-its-a-big-change/ |website=The Beat |accessdate=21 July 2018}} {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! colspan="4" | Best Online Comics Work (2006-2016), Digital Book of the Year (2018-present) |- ! Year ! Title ! Creator(s) ! Vaughan]], [[Marcos Martin]] and Muntsa Vicente | [http://panelsyndicate.com/comics/barrier Panel Syndicate] |} ===Ignatz Awards=== {{Main|Ignatz Award#Outstanding Online Comic}} The Ignatz Awards are intended to recognize outstanding achievements in comics and cartooning by small press creators or creator-owned projects published by larger publishers. They have been awarded each year since 1997, but skipped a year in 2001 due to the show's cancellation after the September 11, 2001 attacks. Recipients of the award are determined by the votes of the attendees of the annual [[Small Press Expo]]. {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! colspan="4" | Outstanding Online Comic |- ! Year ! (webcomic)|OMG Check Please]]'' |[[Ngozi Ukazu]] |[http://www.checkpleasecomic.com/ checkpleasecomic.com] |- | rowspan="2" |2018 |'''Short Form -''' ''Gemma Correll'' |Gemma Correll |[https://www.gemmacorrell.com/ gemmacorrell.com] |- |'''Long Form -''' ''[[Bad Machinery]]'' |[[John Allison (comics)|John Allison]] |[http://scarygoround.com/badmachinery/ar.php scarygoround.com/badmachinery/ar.php] |} ==Other awards== ===Cartoonist Studio Prize=== Presented by the ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate Book Review]]'' and the [[Center for Cartoon Studies]], the Cartoonist Studio Prize was first awarded in 2013 for work produced during the previous year. The award has two categories, "Best Print Comic" and "Best Web Comic". {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! colspan="4" | Best Web Comic |- ! Year ! Title ! Creator(s) ! Website |- | 2013 [http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2013/03/chris_ware_s_building_stories_and_noelle_stevenson_s_nimona_win_the_cartoonist.html] | ''[[Nimona]]'' | [[Noelle Stevenson]] | [http://gingerhaze.com/nimona] |- | 2014 [http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2014/03/cartoonist_studio_prize_2014_taiyo_matsumoto_s_sunny_and_emily_carroll_s.html] | ''Out of Skin'' | [[Emily Carroll]] | [http://www.emcarroll.com/comics/skin/] |- | 2015 [http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2015/04/richard_mcguire_s_here_and_winston_rowntree_s_waiting_win_the_cartoonist.html] | ''Watching'' | [[Winston Rowntree]] | [http://www.viruscomix.com/page585.html] |- | 2016 [http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2016/04/cartoonist_studio_prize_2016_winners_boulet_and_carol_tyler.html] | ''I Want to Believe'' | [[Boulet (comics)|Boulet]] | [http://english.bouletcorp.com/2015/10/21/i-want-to-believe/] |- | 2017 [http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2017/04/cartoonist_studio_prize_2017_winners_eleanor_davis_and_christina_tran.html] | ''On Beauty'' | Christina Tran | [http://sodelightful.com/comics/beauty/] |- | 2018 [https://slate.com/culture/2018/03/cartoonist-studio-prize-2018-winners-keren-katz-and-michael-deforge.html] | ''Leaving Richard's Valley'' | [[Michael DeForge]] | [https://www.instagram.com/richardsvalley/] |} [[File:Xkcd philosophy.png|thumb|right|Munroe's ''[[xkcd]]'' has won [[The Weblog Awards (Wizbang)|The Weblog Awards]]' "Best Comic Strip" twice.]] ===Weblog Awards=== {{Main|The Weblog Awards (Wizbang)}} The Weblog Awards were held from 2003 to 2008 and featured a "best comic strip" category starting in 2006. {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! colspan="4" | Best Comic Strip |- ! Year ! Title ! Creator(s) ! Website |- | 2006 [http://2006.weblogawards.org/] | ''[[Least I Could Do]]'' | [[Ryan Sohmer]] (writer) and Lar deSouza (artist) | [http://www.leasticoulddo.com/ www.leasticoulddo.com] |- | 2007 [http://2007.weblogawards.org/] | ''[[xkcd]]'' | [[Randall Munroe]] | [http://www.xkcd.com/ www.xkcd.com] |- | 2008 [http://2008.weblogawards.org/] | ''xkcd'' | Randall Munroe | [http://www.xkcd.com/ www.xkcd.com] |} ==See also== * [[Webcomic#Awards]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Webcomics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Webcomic awards}} [[Category:Webcomic awards| ]] [[Category:Comics-related lists]] [[Category:Internet-related lists]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[Image:marie-dainton.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Marie Dainton c.1910]]
'''Marie Dainton''' (8 June c. 1881 ‚Äì 1 February 1938) was an actress of the [[Victorian era|Victorian]] and [[Edwardian era]]s who appeared regularly in both [[music hall]]s and in the legitimate theatre.
==Early career== Dainton was born in Russia, apparently in 1881, although other sources cite 1877. Her father was Robert E. Sharlach and her mother was the English actress and singer Jenny Dawson (d. 1936). Dainton made her stage debut on 24 March 1894 at [[York Theatre Royal]] in ''[[Little Red Riding Hood]]''. In this show she gave imitations of well-known theatrical personalities, and this gift for mimicry became her trademark. Dainton became a versatile performer in various theatrical genres, including [[musical comedy]], [[pantomime]] and [[revue]].<ref name=footlights>[http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchiveTextD/MarieDainton.html Dainton on 'Footlights Notes'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928134114/http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchiveTextD/MarieDainton.html |date=28 September 2011 }}</ref>
Dainton made her first London appearance at the Metropolitan music hall in [[Edgware Road]] on 6 August 1894. On 24 December 1894 she opened as 'Mr Falsehood' in ''The House that Jack Built'' at the [[Opera Comique]], and the following year toured as 'Flo' in ''Buttercup and Daisy''. The next few years were spent appearing mainly in the [[music hall]]s until June 1899, when she scored a big success at the [[Avenue Theatre]] giving impressions of popular stage stars in a production entitled ''Pot Pourri''.<ref name=stage>[http://www.stagebeauty.net/th-frames.html Dainton biography on the Stage Beauty website]</ref> In 1898 Dainton appeared in the [[pantomime]] ''[[Puss in Boots]]'' with [[Eugene Stratton]] at the Prince of Wales Theatre in [[Birmingham]].<ref>[http://www.its-behind-you.com/musichall.html The Music Hall Pantomimes website]</ref> She also appeared in the legitimate theatre. Dainton was in demand both in London and on tour in the British provinces and abroad. During 1900 and 1901 she appeared at the [[Casino Theatre (New York City)|Casino Theatre]] in New York, and at the [[Apollo Theatre]] in London, as Paquita in ''[[The Belle of Bohemia]]''. In New York she was temporarily restrained from appearing in the show until a breach of contract case was resolved in the courts.<ref>"Marie Dainton Enjoined", ''New York Times'', 20 November 1900</ref> She also toured [[Austria]] as Fifi in ''[[The Belle of New York (musical)|The Belle of New York]]''. At the [[Royal Strand Theatre|Strand Theatre]] in London in 1902 she appeared in the successful musical play ''[[A Chinese Honeymoon]]''. In 1902 she made several gramophone recordings for the [[Gramophone Company|Gramophone & Typewriter Co Ltd]] and [[Path√©]] of songs from this show, namely "The √† la Girl", "Sweet Little Sing-Sing", and "Mandie of Ohio".<ref name=footlights/>
==Later years== [[Image:marie-dainton2.jpg|thumb|right|Marie Dainton]] Dainton was the original ''[[Peggy Machree]]'' at [[Wyndham's Theatre]] in London from 28 December 1904, and played the leading role in the original production of ''[[The Girl Behind the Counter]]'', again at Wyndham's, from 21 April 1906. Dainton was a leading figure in the [[Music hall#.27Music Hall War.27 of 1907|Music Hall War]] of 1907,<ref name=stage/> alongside, among others, [[Joe Elvin]], [[Gus Elen]] and [[Marie Lloyd]]. At the [[Colonial Theatre (New York City)|Colonial Theatre]] in New York in March 1909 Dainton appeared in [[vaudeville]], again performing her mimicry of celebrities, including [[Harry Lauder]], [[Anna Held]], [[Marie Tempest]], [[Marie Lloyd]] and [[Mrs Patrick Campbell]].<ref>The New York Dramatic Mirror, New York, Saturday, 20 March 1909, p.9</ref>
In October 1909 Dainton made a second tour of the United States, playing in [[Philadelphia]] and Chicago in ''The Silver Star'' and ''Madame Sherry''. In 1910 she toured the English provinces as Clarice in the opera ''[[The Mountaineers (opera)|The Mountaineers]]'' before returning to the [[music hall]]s. Among other productions, she took part in ''[[The Gay Hussars|Autumn Manoeuvres]]'' on tour in 1912, ''I Should Worry'' at The [[Palace Theatre, London|Palace Theatre]] and on tour in 1913.
She appeared in ''Society Ltd'' in 1920, ''Riverside Nights'' in 1926, ''The Eternal Flame'' in 1929, and in ''Getting George Married'' in 1930.<ref name=stage/> Her last appearances took place in the early 1930s, playing the Duchess of Capablanca in ''The Werewolf'', an eight performance run produced at the [[Kingsway Theatre]], London, on 9 November 1932 by the Independent Theatre Club; and as a Slut in the play ''Mary Read'' at London's [[Phoenix Theatre (London)|Phoenix Theatre]] in 1934.<ref name=footlights/>
==Death== Marie Dainton died in London on 1 February 1938. {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110928134114/http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchiveTextD/MarieDainton.html Dainton biography on Footlights Notes website] *{{IBDB name|37120}} *[http://digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchdetail.cfm?trg=1&strucID=215354&imageID=408830&parent_id=113607&word=&snum=&s=&notword=&d=&c=&f=&sScope=&sLevel=&sLabel=&total=50&num=0&imgs=12&pNum=&pos=10 Dainton on [[New York Public Library]] Digital Gallery] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090512211232/http://www.philcoradio.com/zena/others.htm Portrait of Dainton on The [[Zena Dare]] Page] *[http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait.php?LinkID=mp86575&rNo=0&role=sit Portrait of Dainton on the [[National Portrait Gallery (London)|National Portrait Gallery]] website]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dainton, Marie}} [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:English women comedians]] [[Category:English female singers]] [[Category:Music hall performers]] [[Category:English stage actresses]] [[Category:English opera singers]] [[Category:Vaudeville performers]] [[Category:Women of the Victorian era]] [[Category:1881 births]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = Maximum Fighting Championship |logo = [[File:Maximum fighting championship logo.jpg]] |type = Private |foundation = 2001-2014 |founder = Mark Pavelich |industry = [[Mixed martial arts]] promotion |parent = Pavelich Sports Inc. |sibling = |slogan = |homepage = http://www.maximumfighting.com |location_city = [[Edmonton, Alberta]] |location_country= Canada |key_people = Mark Pavelich (CEO)
Dave Pavelich (Vice-President)
Manon Pavelich (Treasurer/Tickets)http://www.maximumfighting.com/history.htm{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} }} '''Maximum Fighting Championship''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[mixed martial arts]] (MMA) promotion based in [[Edmonton, Alberta]]. MFC‚Äôs former home, in Canada, is the River Cree Resort and Casino in Enoch, Alberta, located just outside Edmonton, Alberta but has also held events at the [[Edmonton Expo Centre]].{{cite web|url=http://mmamania.com/2010/5/8/1463318/mfc-25-results-recap-and-post|title=MFC 25 results, recap and post-fight discussion for 'Vindication' on May 7|author=James Iannotti|work=MMAmania.com|accessdate=6 June 2015}} MFC events are broadcast on [[The Fight Network]], [[AXS TV]] (formerly HDnet) in [[North America]] and most recently [[TSN2]]. MFC is known to be the biggest MMA promotion in Canada and one of the top MMA shows in the World. MFC has notable Canadian fighters, such as [[Ryan Jimmo]], Graham Spencer, [[Tom Watson (fighter)|Tom Watson]] and [[Douglas Lima]], plus MMA veterans, such as [[Jason MacDonald]], [[Thales Leites]], [[Jay Silva]], [[Trevor Prangley]], and [[Paul Daley]].http://www.maximumfighting.com/mfcorg.htm{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==History== Maximum Fighting Championship was founded on March 3, 2001, by Pavelich Sports Inc. Mark Pavelich is the CEO of MFC and runs the business day to day. Dave Pavelich is Vice President and Manon Pavelich is the booker. MFC currently airs on [[AXS TV Fights]] in the U.S. and [[The Fight Network]] in Canada. MFC‚Äôs former home was the ''River Cree Resort and Casino'' in Enoch, Alberta, Canada located just outside Edmonton, Alberta. Their new home is the ''Mayfield Inn Trade and Conference Centre'' Edmonton, Alberta. In July 2011, MFC signed a five-year live TV deal with [[HDnet]] (now [[AXS TV]]) and in October 2011, MFC signed with [[TSN2]]. MFC hosts heavyweight fights but doesn't have a heavyweight championship due to the lack of heavyweights outside of the top promotions. MFC employs the Unified Rules of Mixed Martial Arts. All MFC bouts take place in a [[Boxing ring|ring]], with the exception of MFC 29 which, in accordance with the regulations utilized in Ontario which requires all mixed martial arts fights to be held in a cage structure, took place in a circular cage named "''The Ring''" by the winner of a "''Name the Cage''" fan contest.{{cite web|url=http://www.maximumfighting.com/news/mfc-stays-in-the-ring/|title=MFC stays in THE RING|publisher=maximumfighting.com|date=2011-04-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225100900/http://www.maximumfighting.com/news/mfc-stays-in-the-ring/|archivedate=2013-12-25|df=}} In 2012, MFC announced the re-launched its heavyweight division and the upcoming debut of a featherweight division. In 2013, the Maximum Fighting Championship also announced that the organization would add a bantamweight with the debut bout taking place on May 19, 2013 at MFC 37: True Grit. MFC has not held an event since MFC 41 'All In" on October 3, 2014. Mark Pavelich announced that Maximum Fighting Championship was up for sale on February 18, 2016. {{cite web|url=http://www.mmaweekly.com/maximum-fighting-championship-is-for-sale|title=Maximum Fighting Championship is For Sale - MMAWeekly.com|author=|date=|website=www.mmaweekly.com|accessdate=23 April 2018}} ==Rules== MFC employs the [[Unified Rules of Mixed Martial Arts]]. ===Rounds=== Every round in MFC competition is five minutes in duration. Title matches have five such rounds, and non-title matches have three. There is a one-minute rest period between rounds.http://www.maximumfighting.com/rules.htm{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Weight divisions=== {{See also|Mixed martial arts weight classes}} MFC currently uses six weight classes: {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%; text-align:center;" !rowspan="2"|Weight class name !colspan="2"|Upper limit |- !in [[Pound (mass)|pounds]] (lb) !in [[kilogram]]s (kg) |- |align="left"|[[Bantamweight (MMA)|Bantamweight]] |135||61 |- |align="left"|[[Lightweight (MMA)|Featherweight]] |145||66 |- |align="left"|[[Lightweight (MMA)|Lightweight]] |155||70 |- |align="left"|[[Welterweight (MMA)|Welterweight]] |170||77 |- |align="left"|[[Middleweight (MMA)|Middleweight]] |185||84 |- |align="left"|[[Light Heavyweight (MMA)|Light Heavyweight]] |205||93 |- |align="left"|[[Heavyweight (MMA)|Heavyweight]] |265||120 |- |[[Super heavyweight (MMA)|Super Heavyweight]] | colspan=2|No weight limit |- |} ===Attire=== All competitors must fight in approved shorts, without shoes. Shirts, [[Keikogi|gis]] or long pants (including gi pants) are not allowed. Fighters must use approved light-weight open-fingered gloves, that include at least 1" of padding around the knuckles, (110 to 170 g / 4 to 6 ounces) that allow fingers to grab. These gloves enable fighters to punch with less risk of an injured or broken hand, while retaining the ability to grab and grapple. ===Match outcome=== Matches usually end via: *'''[[Submission (combat sport term)|Submission]]''': a fighter clearly taps on the mat or his opponent or verbally submits. *'''Technical Submission''': A technical submission is achieved when the referee stops a fight due to an injury resulting from a submission hold or due to a fighter going unconscious from a choke. *'''[[Knockout]]''': a fighter falls from a legal blow and is either unconscious or unable to immediately continue. *'''Technical Knockout''' (TKO): If a fighter cannot continue, the fight is ended as a technical knockout. Technical knockouts can be classified into three categories: **referee stoppage: (the referee determines a fighter cannot "intelligently defend" himself; if warnings to the fighter to improve his position or defense go unanswered‚Äîgenerally, two warnings are given, about 5 seconds apart) **doctor stoppage (a ringside doctor due to injury or impending injury, as when blood flows into the eyes and blinds a fighter) **corner stoppage (a fighter's own corner-man signals defeat for their own fighter) *'''Judges' Decision''': Depending on scoring, a match may end as: **unanimous decision (all three judges score a win for fighter A) **majority decision (two judges score a win for fighter A, one judge scores a draw) **split decision (two judges score a win for fighter A, one judge scores a win for fighter B) **unanimous draw (all three judges score a draw) **majority draw (two judges score a draw, one judge scoring a win) **split draw (one judge scores a win for fighter A, one judge scores a win for fighter B, and one judge scores a draw) Note: In the event of a draw, it is not necessary that the fighters' total ''points'' be equal. However, in a unanimous or split draw, each fighter does score an equal number of ''win judgments'' from the three judges (0 or 1, respectively). A fight can also end in a '''technical decision''', '''disqualification''', '''forfeit''', '''technical draw''', or '''no contest'''. The latter two outcomes have no winners. ===Judging criteria=== The [[10-point must system|ten-point must system]] is in effect for all fights; three judges score each round and the winner of each receives ten points, the loser nine points or fewer. If the round is even, both fighters receive ten points. ===Fouls=== The Nevada State Athletic Commission currently lists the following as fouls:[http://www.leg.state.nv.us/NAC/NAC-467.html NSAC Regulations: Chapter 467 - Unarmed Combat]. Nevada State Athletic Commission. Retrieved April 3, 2006 #[[headbutt|Butting]] with the head #[[eye-gouging|Eye gouging]] of any kind #Biting #Hair pulling #[[fish-hooking|Fish hooking]] #[[Groin attack]]s of any kind #Putting a finger into any orifice or into any cut or laceration on an opponent. (see [[Gouging (fighting style)|Gouging]]) #[[Small joint manipulation]] #Striking to the spine or the back of the head (see [[Rabbit punch]]) #Striking downward using the point of the elbow (see [[Elbow (strike)]]) #[[Throat]] strikes of any kind, including, without limitation, grabbing the [[Vertebrate trachea|trachea]] #Clawing, pinching or twisting the flesh #Grabbing the [[clavicle]] #[[soccer kick|Kicking]] the head of a grounded opponent #[[knee (strike)|Kneeing]] the head of a grounded opponent #[[stomp (strike)|Stomping]] a grounded opponent #[[Kick]]ing to the kidney with the heel #Spiking an opponent to the canvas on his head or neck. (see [[piledriver (professional wrestling)|piledriver]]) #[[throw (grappling)|Throwing]] an opponent out of the ring or fenced area #Holding the shorts or gloves of an opponent #Spitting at an opponent #Engaging in unsportsmanlike conduct that causes an injury to an opponent #Holding the ropes or the fence #Using abusive language in the ring or fenced area #Attacking an opponent on or during the break #Attacking an opponent who is under the care of the referee #Attacking an opponent after the bell (horn) has sounded the end of a round #Flagrantly disregarding the instructions of the referee #Timidity, including, without limitation, avoiding contact with an opponent, intentionally or consistently dropping the mouthpiece or faking an injury #Interference by the corner #Throwing in the towel during competition When a foul is charged, the referee in their discretion may deduct one or more points as a penalty. If a foul incapacitates a fighter, then the match may end in a disqualification if the foul was intentional, or a no contest if unintentional. If a foul causes a fighter to be unable to continue later in the bout, it ends with a technical decision win to the injured fighter if the injured fighter is ahead on points, otherwise it is a technical draw. ===Match conduct=== * After a verbal warning the referee can stop the fighters and stand them up if they reach a stalemate on the ground (where neither are in a dominant [[Grappling position|position]] or working towards one). * If the referee pauses the match, it is resumed with the fighters in their prior positions. * Grabbing the ring ropes brings a verbal warning, followed by an attempt by the referee to release the grab by pulling on the grabbing hand. If that attempt fails or if the fighter continues to hold the ropes, the referee may charge a foul. ===Title fights=== On September 18, 2012 MFC instituted new regulations regarding title fights.{{cite web|url=http://www.mmamania.com/2012/9/18/3354394/maximum-fighting-championship-mfc-weigh-in-drug-testing|title=Maximum Fighting Championship (MFC) institutes new regulations for title fights, weigh-ins and drug testing|publisher=MMAmania.com|date=2012-09-18}} '''Title Fight with a reigning/defending champion''' *If the champion fails to make weight: **SCENARIO 1 - The champion vacates the title immediately. The fight remains a five-round contest. If the vacated champion wins the fight, the Maximum Fighting Championship holds the option to automatically consider him the No. 1 contender for the next title fight in that weight class. The Maximum Fighting Championship also holds an option to make an immediate rematch. **SCENARIO 2 - The champion vacates the title immediately. The fight remains a five-round contest. If the challenger wins the fight, the challenger becomes the MFC champion. The Maximum Fighting Championship holds an option to make an immediate rematch. *If the challenger fails to make weight: **The champion automatically retains the belt. A non-title fight takes place and the Maximum Fighting Championship solely determines if the bout is a three- or five-round fight. If the challenger wins the bout, the Maximum Fighting Championship holds an option to make a future rematch. *If both fighters fail to make weight: **The champion vacates the title immediately. A non-title fight takes place and the Maximum Fighting Championship solely determines if the bout is a three- or five-round fight. The Maximum Fighting Championship holds the option to consider the winner of the bout as the No. 1 contender for the next title fight in that weight class. The Maximum Fighting Championship also holds an option to make future rematch. '''Title Fight with a vacant championship''' *If one fighter fails to make weight: **The fight remains a five-round contest. If the fighter who made weight wins the bout, he becomes the MFC champion of that weight class. If the fighter who failed to make weight wins the bout, that fighter does not claim the title, and the Maximum Fighting Championship holds the option to make him the No. 1 contender and/or to make an immediate rematch. *If both fighters fail to make weight: **A non-title bout takes place and the Maximum Fighting Championship solely determines if the bout is a three- or five-round fight. The Maximum Fighting Championship holds the option to make a future rematch. ==Events== {{Main article|List of MFC events}} As of October 3, 2014, the Maximum Fighting Championship has held a total of '''44''' events, all of which have taken place in [[Alberta]], Canada with the exception of MFC 29 which took place in [[Windsor, Ontario]], Canada. ==Current champions== {| style="border-collapse: collapse;" border="1" cellpadding="3" |- bgcolor="#FFFFCC" ! Division ! Upper weight limit ! Champion ! Since ! Title Defenses ! Edmonton, Alberta, Canada |align=center | February 15, 2013 | |- |align="center" colspan="5"|''Spencer vacated the title on November 28, 2013 due to lingering injuries.
